content.description:
Starts in a cavern below and to the left of the very large boulder located in the "Dinner Bowl" area. A fun little splitter that's great for practicing your crack climbing or laybacking technique.



A few hand sized cams. Bolted anchor.

Doesn't look too bad from the ground until you get on it and realize that every single hold faces left. May be Manitoba's first for the grade?

Setting up a top rope on this one is a bit of pain, but is doable. Easiest method is to rap in from the anchor above "If You've Got Time To Lean..." and swing over to access the anchor for Bojo's.


3 bolts. Anchor with quicklinks for lowering.

Follow the crack system to a crux about two thirds up. After pulling the crux, go left around the small tree, following the crack to anchors. 


Singles 0.3-3. Bolted anchor with quicklinks for lowering.

After a slightly techy first couple moves, climb up an incut flake to a mantle onto a ledge. Climb the dihedral, pulling awkwardly onto a bulge. Follow the crack system to the top.



To easily set up a top rope, approach from the ledge system climbers left of the route. 

Singles 0.3 - 3. A #4 can be nice but isn't needed. Bolted anchor with quicklinks for lowering.

Follow the finger/hand crack in the corner, making use of the slab for a couple moves before pulling a small roof. 


Singles to #1. Bolted anchor with quick links for lowering.

An aesthetic dihedral featuring a bit of everything. Follow the great corner crack, pull some awkward moves to get through the offwidth, and take the slab to the anchors. 



In order to set up a top rope on this you would have to rap in to the anchors as they are located on the face. There are a couple good trees a ways back from the edge at top of the cliff to use as an anchor if you want to rap in to set up a top rope.


Singles from #0.75 to #4. A #6 or a #7 if you have one is recommended for protecting the offwidth and the slab moves above it to the anchor, but isn't essential. If you don't have any big cams, place a solid #3 and/or #4 at the top of the crack and run it out to the anchor.  Bolted anchor with rings for lowering.

Steep and bouldery at the bottom, with a techy crux up high, this route may be short but it makes you work for it. 

This route was originally sent on gear. However, after the first ascent, two large blocks were removed, changing the character of the route. As it now climbs like a sport climb and the gear is flared and thin, bolts were installed. Whether you just clip the bolts, clip some and supplement with gear, or do the whole thing on gear, this is a route worth getting on!


3 Bolts. If you choose to forego clipping them, a rack of small gear will work.

The squeeze chimney. You might love it, you might hate it, you might love it then hate it. It's worth the try to find out!


3 bolts to the anchor.

The route begins in a short squeeze chimney. At the top of the chimney, use the ledge to gain the horizontal crack. Traverse right to reach a vertical hand crack. Follow the crack to the anchors.



#0.5 to #3 cams, an extra #2 is nice to have. Bolted anchor with quicklinks.

Climb the corner following a crack system. You can jam, layback, or any combination thereof.  A great route for beginners and an excellent first lead for a new trad climber. 


Singles, 0.3 - 3

The easiest of the bolted routes at White Lake, with closely spaced bolts and good clipping stances, this is a great lead for newer outdoor leaders. Short relative to other routes at the crag but with fun, consistent movement.



From start of "Devil's in the DEEtails" walk through the bottom of the chimney and turn right at the exit. 

4 bolts

An absolutely splitter fist crack with a decent sized roof to pull. A White Lake classic!



I'd recommend at least two #4s, three if you don't feel super confident on wide fist jams, and one #3. Bolted anchor with quicklinks for lowering.

Climb the face, pull a couple challenging moves to a small ledge at the base of the dihedral. From the ledge, clip the last bolt and commit to some insecure moves through to the anchor. White Lake's finest sport climb and a test piece for the grade



5 bolts to a bolted anchor with rings for lowering

climbs.name: If You've Got Time to Lean, You've Got Time to Clean

content.description:
Work your way up the corner, using a mix of chimney, crack and face techniques. 


Singles #0.3 to #1, bolted anchor with quicklinks for lowering.

Crux is near the top. Interesting moves near the top using the arete on climber's left make it feel easier, while avoiding the arete and chockstones make it closer to 5.9. There looks to be an abandoned nest near the top of the chockstones, so check there are no birds before climbing this or Devil's In The DEETails. Start at the small tunnel entrance that accesses Devil's In The DEETails. Climb the thin finger crack all the way up.

Good small protection from bottom to top. Larger placements aren't very secure due to the crack flaring out. No bolts at the top yet so bring plenty of static rope. Description will be updated once bolts are added.

A cruxy start leads to fun slab climbing finishing with a small traverse under a roof. For top rope you may want to consider using a directional draw on the third bolt. 


3 Bolts. Shares an anchor with "If You've Got Time to Lean, You've Got Time to Clean"

Avoids the reachy crux to get to the first bolt of Simp the Crimp. Start to the left of Simp the Crimp, around the small corner on a slab with one bolt. Once you've reached the ledge the route joins with Simp the Crimp at it's second bolt.


3 Bolts. Shares an anchor with "If You've Got Time to Lean, You've Got Time to Clean"

Work your way up a technical face, making a couple awkward moves in thin crack to pull over the bulge. Continue up, following the crack system as it trends leftwards.


Singles to #3, stoppers can be useful. Bolted anchor.

Climb a short slab into a corner, pull a couple challenging moves to get through the roof, continue following the crack, going left at a small tree to reach the anchor. 



To access the anchor to set up a top rope, rappel in from the anchor located back from the cliff edge.

Bring a handful of small to medium cams. Bolted anchor with quicklinks.

Climb the vertical face on a large boulder located at the bottom of the cliff. From the top of the boulder, take the thin crack to the top, going right of the small tree.



To access the anchor to set up a top rope, rappel in from the anchor located back from the cliff edge.

Small to medium sized cams. Stoppers. Bolted anchor with quicklinks.

The Campground Crag is a small granite cliff featuring a variety of moderate trad climbs and a number of sport routes. All anchors are bolted, and most routes can easily be top roped. The climbs tend to be short but sustained, with the cliff topping out around 40-50 feet. With grades ranging from 5.7 to 5.12b, there's something for everyone at White Lake. As the wall is north facing, it gets shade for most of the day, making it an excellent choice for warmer days. Like most climbing in this part of the world though, the best time of year for climbing here is late spring and early fall, when temps are ideal and bugs are sparse.
